executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2022 currency. 

The Antiseptic Manufacturing industry has expanded, albeit moderately, over the five years to 2022 due to heightened demand from the industry's key markets, including healthcare and household consumers. During the five-year period, demand for antiseptics has increased alongside rising total health expenditure, largely fueled by the expanding medical needs of an aging US population. While the outbreak of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) caused healthcare systems to divert resources into pandemic management and defer surgical procedures, reducing demand for some industry products, diversification in the industry's products and end markets shielded it from a stronger decline. Following vaccine availability in 2021, a recovery in total health expenditure fueled by pent-up demand for elective procedures has supported revenue growth. Although the industry remains susceptible to risks related to new variants, vaccination rates, and supply chain logistics, industry revenue is expected to increase, rising an annualized 0.7% to $1.1 billion over the five years to 2022, including an increase of 2.9% in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Healthcare antiseptics, which largely consist of surgical scrubs and preoperative skin preparations for patients, are used by healthcare professionals. The target markets of healthcare antiseptics are hospitals, doctor offices, outpatient settings and nursing homes.

Food handler antiseptics consist of hand washes and sanitizers, which are used in restaurants and other commercial food establishments, as well as food processing, manufacturing and distribution facilities.

Consumer antiseptics target the general public and include antiseptic washes and antimicrobial ointments and sanitizers. Generally, most consumer antiseptic products are bundled with first aid kits and similar packaging for sale to households, small businesses and schools.

Industry revenue is expected to increase an annualized 0.7% to $1.1 billion over the five years to 2022, including an increase of 2.9% in 2022 alone. During most of the period, demand for healthcare-related antiseptic products grew appreciably as an aging US population led to rising doctor visits. Additionally, spending on consumer antiseptics has improved over the past five years as rising employment and disposable income levels have prompted health-conscious consumers to spend more on personal antiseptic products, which are considered discretionary purchases by most households.

While domestic demand for antiseptics has steadily expanded over the five years to 2022, import penetration into the industry has risen as well. Increased import penetration can generally be explained by an appreciating US dollar, which makes domestically produced goods more expensive relative to their foreign counterparts, and rising competition from lower-cost alternatives available from manufacturers overseas that benefit from lower labor costs. For instance, imports accounted for 42.9% of domestic demand in 2020, compared with 41.6% in 2022, as the US dollar appreciated as investors sought out safe haven currencies amid global economic uncertainty.

Antiseptics are used to prevent infection by microorganisms and differ from disinfectants, though they often contain the same ingredients and are used for the same purpose. Since antiseptics are used on humans, all categories of antiseptics are regulated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). To bring an antiseptic to market, its manufacturer has two options, the new drug application process or the over-the-counter (OTC) drug review. Most antiseptic products are currently being marketed as OTC healthcare antiseptic drug products. In recent years, the FDA has issued warnings to antiseptic manufacturers with regard to both the safety and efficacy of their products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The vitality and expansion of the US healthcare sector is expected to underpin steadily rising demand for antiseptic products over the coming years. This trend will be strengthened by the aging population's heightened need for medical services, supported largely be an expected expansion in federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid, which is projected to increase an annualized 6.0% over the five years to 2027. Total health expenditure is expected increase an annualized 3.3% during the same period.

Over the five years to 2027, trends are expected to reflect conditions exhibited during the current period in terms of a growing number of operators and high import penetration. Internal competition will likely stem from the development of new antiseptic solutions by new market entrants. Overall, the number of industry enterprises is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 2.5% to 186 companies over the five years to 2027. Meanwhile, industry employment is expected to rise an annualized 2.4% to 6,883 workers during the same period.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures antiseptic ampoules, tablets, capsules, vials, ointments, powders, solutions and suspensions.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - increasing

key_trends: An expanding senior population has boosted demand for industry products
An appreciating US dollar has increased import penetration
Significant disruptions to global transportation channels constrained profit growth
Rising health expenditure in foreign countries is likely to boost industry revenue
Internal competition will stem from new antiseptic solutions developed by new entrants
Increased compliance costs associated with safety and efficacy testing are likely to temper profitability
Strong trade interdependencies between countries for medical goods has consistently supported industry exports

market_segmentation.segment_description: Healthcare establishments are by far the largest market for industry products, accounting for an estimated 48.0% of industry revenue in 2022.
Industrial and commercial clients are expected to account for 17.7% of industry revenue in 2022. This market segment encompasses businesses across all sectors except for healthcare.

The industry's export market is anticipated to increase during the five-year period. Exports are anticipated to rise as a share of industry revenue during the period, from 14.6% in 2017 to an estimated 15.7%.
Consumers constitute a small, yet steadily growing market for industry products, accounting for an estimated 12.6% of industry revenue in 2022.
Miscellaneous markets account for the remaining 6.0% of industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: The alcohols category, which includes all antiseptic products that contain the active ingredients isopropyl and ethyl alcohol (ethanol), is expected to account for a combined 59.7% of industry revenue in 2022.
Benzalkonium chloride (BZK)-containing antiseptic products are expected to account for 11.4% of industry revenue in 2022.
Iodine-based antiseptic products account for an estimated 10.1% of industry revenue.
All other antiseptic categories account for the remaining 12.5% of industry revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Organic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Plastic Products Miscellaneous Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Pharmacies & Drug Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The largest and most profitable market for industry products is the healthcare sector, which uses antiseptics for infection control, preoperative skin preparation, as well as a variety of other professional applications.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Industrial and Commercial Users
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The primary driver of demand for antiseptics from the commercial market is regulatory compliance. For example, increased food safety regulations from the FDA and the US Department of Health and Human Services drives demand for topical antiseptics from the food service and manufacturing markets.
Noneconomic drivers of demand include population growth and demographics, health consciousness and changing regulations associated with infection control, food handling and labor safety.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The total value of imports from foreign manufacturers has increased over the past five years, rising at an estimated annualized rate of 5.2% through 2022.
Over the past five years, the value of industry exports has increased at an annualized rate of 2.2% to $178.9 million, accounting for 15.7% of industry revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The West region of the United States.
The Mid-Atlantic region of the United States.
The Southeast region of the United States.
The Great Lakes region of the United States.
The Southwest region of the United States.
The New England region of the United States.
The Rocky Mountains region of the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry's most relevant regulating body is the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Industry products are considered drugs and are subject to FDA oversight.
The FDA has proposed plans to change the monograph on OTC topical antiseptics used in healthcare settings, requiring manufacturers to prove safety and effectiveness through trials.
Industry operators are also subject to regulations from the FTC, EPA, OSHA, and private standard setting organizations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Changing regulations regarding the safety and efficacy of consumer and healthcare antiseptics have increased barriers to entry.
Technical barriers to entry, such as regulatory hurdles and initial capital requirements, may prevent newcomers with limited resources from entering the industry altogether.

A medium level of market share concentration, intense price-based competition and a highly saturated market for industry goods make it difficult for new operators to expand their business once they enter the market.

Barriers to entry vary widely across market segments, with operators serving the professional healthcare and industrial experiencing the greatest barriers. Conversely, new entrants seeking to enter the retail market for antiseptics currently experience the lowest barriers to entry.

factors_increased_barrier: Ongoing supply chain disruptions benefiting larger companies

basis_points.basis_title: Competition varies across product and market segments
basis_points.basis_description: The majority of products manufactured by this industry, particularly alcohol or benzalkonium chloride swabs used for preoperative prep or wound care, are highly commoditized products sold at razor thin margins. Thus, companies that primarily produce these products compete on the basis of price and product purity, rather than technical expertise or product specialization.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition in consumer and non-industrial commercial markets
basis_points.basis_description: Companies that primarily market to the consumer and non-industrial commercial markets (e.g., small businesses and offices) typically also compete on the basis of price, brand recognition and range of product selection.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition in professional healthcare and industrial markets
basis_points.basis_description: Operators that mostly serve the professional healthcare and industrial markets generally compete on the basis of proven product safety and effectiveness, technical expertise and, to a lesser extent, price.

basis_points.basis_title: Purchasing power of GPOs and IDNs
basis_points.basis_description: The healthcare market for antiseptic products is particularly competitive since many healthcare establishments purchase antiseptic products via intermediary group purchasing organizations (GPOs), integrated delivery networks (IDNs) or medical wholesalers, rather than directly from the manufacturer.

Regulatory changes during the past five years have also increased the level of competition within this market segment. The FDA recently proposed new monograph guidelines for topical antiseptics used in healthcare environments requiring manufacturers to prove product safety and effectiveness through trials.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 companies account for 45.7% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four operators are expected to account for 45.7% of industry revenue in 2022.

Becton, Dickinson and Company (BD), a leading supplier of infection control products to the healthcare market, is the only US-based operator with more than a 5.0% share of the market at 40.2% in 2022.
This highly fragmented industry comprises a wide range of operators that produce antiseptic products for the professional healthcare, consumer health and industrial markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Changes in raw material prices can adversely affect an operator's profit margins, given the significant share of purchases within an operator's budget.
Wages have risen as a share of revenue since 2017, as operators increase their labor force and invest in research and development (R&D).
Ongoing supply chain disruptions related to the COVID-19 (coronavirus) has led to price fluctuations in raw materials and freight charges, although disruptions are expected to ease throughout 2022.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Ratio of depreciation to labor costs
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every dollar that the average industry operator spends on labor in 2022, an estimated $0.22 will be invested in capital expenditures, such as production line equipment.
Still, the industry remains dependent on human labor and highly knowledgeable, high-wage research and development personnel to formulate antiseptic and antimicrobial products.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry produces a diversified range of products which are sold to downstream consumers in the healthcare, food and consumer sectors, among others, somewhat shielding the industry from revenue fluctuations.
However, the industry is susceptible to changes in export and import activity, as industry operators rely on exports for a significant share of revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: At the forefront of technological advancement are highly specialized biotech companies whose primary focus is developing new antimicrobial products.

The majority of industry operators are not involved in new product research, but rather reformulation of existing products to meet the changing needs of healthcare professionals, food handling establishments and other key markets.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: In response to competitive pressure, many companies within the industry have specialized in higher value-added products to justify higher selling prices.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Given the nondiscretionary nature of industry products, macroeconomic conditions, such as consumer confidence and disposable income, do not completely influence demand for industry products.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: The industry's labor costs are significant, accounting for an expected 10.3% of revenue in 2022. To minimize production costs and bolster margins, some companies have opted to shift production to areas where labor costs are lower.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in the price of chemical inputs can have a significant impact on companies' purchase costs, ultimately impacting their profit margins.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: By investing more in capital machinery and equipment, industry operators have managed to minimize their demand for labor, preserving their margins.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Through the increased implementation of capital and equipment, many industry operators have been able to develop technologically advanced products that tend to be more effective than lower cost alternatives.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies benefit from membership in trade associations, such as the American Cleaning Institute and the Cosmetic, Toiletry, and Fragrance Association.

FAQs.question: How have regulations impacted your ability to manufacture your products?
FAQs.answer: Since topical antiseptics are primarily marketed for health-related purposes, industry products are considered drugs and are therefore subject to oversight by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Companies face high pressure from downstream buyers to lower selling prices. However, companies that specialize in premium products have benefited from favorable demand conditions, boosting both revenue and profitability.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Expenditure on wages in this industry accounts for a larger portion of revenue than expenditure on capital. IBISWorld estimates that a typical company in this industry spends $0.29 on capital equipment for each dollar spent on labor in 2018.

FAQs.question: How does your company use advanced technology and techniques to its advantage? How are you able to stay up-to-date with new technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies must have access to the latest technology and drug production methods, either by investing in research and development or acquiring it through the purchase of other enterprises with patented technology.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your company complies with regulations? Have you previously experienced compliance difficulties?
FAQs.answer: Although OTC antiseptic manufacturers are subject to a lower level of regulation than other medical product manufacturers, industry operators must still comply with FDA and FTC guidelines on acceptable doses, ingredient interactions and packaging.

FAQs.question: What quality control processes do you have in effect? Is your company known for the quality of its services?
FAQs.answer: Ensuring high quality is paramount because contaminated or improperly blended antiseptics can cause major health issues. Tainted products have historically subjected operators to major civil and criminal lawsuits in the past.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is generated from exports? How much competition from imports do you face in the domestic market?
An increase in the TWI reflects an appreciation of the US dollar
FAQs.answer: An increase in the TWI reflects an appreciation of the US dollar, which makes domestically produced goods more expensive for foreign buyers and renders imports more affordable in the US market, both of which have an adverse impact on industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue comes from the food manufacturing sector? Do you experience fluctuating demand?
FAQs.answer: Food manufacturers and food service businesses are major users of industry products.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue comes from the healthcare sector? How closely do you track total health expenditure?
FAQs.answer: An increase in total health expenditure has a positive impact on industry demand and revenue.
